texts.definition: The action of introducing or rearranging game elements to create structures in game states or game worlds.
markups: <style="Definition">The action of introducing or rearranging game elements to create structures in game states or game worlds.</style>

Building is a common activity possible in games; this may be actual constructions or simply actions that are diegetically presented as constructing something but other possibilities exist. One is that players may construct their own set of game elements to bring to a game, which may include actually building or creating them also. Another is that the main activity for players is to create the code that will be performing the actual gameplay. A third is that the story told by the game is seen as something constructed during gameplay.

Building houses and hotels in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Monopoly">Monopoly</link></style> and pyramids in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Amun-Re">Amun-Re</link></style> are simple examples of how game actions can represent <style="CurrentLink">Construction</style>, and this exists in computer games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/FarmVille">FarmVille</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ravenwood%20Fair">Ravenwood Fair</link></style> as well although in these players may need the help of other players to complete the building projects. The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Sims%20series">Sims series</link></style> combines this with controlling the 'Sims' or simply letting them behave as they wish in the houses constructed by the players. Games such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/SimCity%20series">SimCity series</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Incredible%20Machine%20game%20series">Incredible Machine game series</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pontifex">Pontifex</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Minecraft">Minecraft</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Slaves%20to%20Armok%20II:%20Dwarf%20Fortress">Slaves to Armok II: Dwarf Fortress</link></style> all focus heavily on building, and the two latter do that to a level of complexity that players have constructed computers within the games.

The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Age%20of%20Empires">Age of Empires</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Civilization%20(video%20game)%20series">Civilization series</link></style> show how units can be the result of <style="CurrentLink">Construction</style> while <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Carcassonne">Carcassonne</link></style> shows how it can be used to create the game world as the game is being played. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Spore">Spore</link></style> is noteworthy in that it supports <style="CurrentLink">Construction</style> on many different levels throughout the gameplay: from characteristics of microorganism to the development of bases on other planets as well as terraforming them. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/P-Robots">P-Robots</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Crobots">Crobots</link></style> are games where the only influence players can have on the gameplay is how they program the robots. Although <style="CurrentLink">Construction</style> is part of the diegesis of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Puerto%20Rico">Puerto Rico</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Race%20for%20the%20Galaxy">Race for the Galaxy</link></style>, here players win or lose by how they build the functionality of their colonies and empires respectively, and an important part of mastering the game is knowing how to construct efficient combinations.

Some games make construction privileged actions for some players. Typical cases for this is so-called 'class-based' <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:FPS%20Games">FPS Games</link></style>, for example the 'engineer' class in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Team%20Fortress%20series">Team Fortress series</link></style>

and the 'field ops', 'engineer', 'constructor', and 'technician' classes in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Enemy%20Territory:%20Quake%20Wars">Enemy Territory: Quake Wars</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Warhammer%20Fantasy%20Roleplay">Warhammer Fantasy Roleplay</link></style> most often have ready-made game worlds and narratives but the final touches are made by the game masters, besides that players often get to create their own characters. This was continued in early <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Massively%20Multiplayer%20Online%20Games">Massively Multiplayer Online Games</link></style>, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Kingdoms">Kingdoms</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/DragonMud">DragonMud</link></style>, where players that had shown their commitment could expand the game rules and game world. Some of the later commercial versions, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ultima%20Online">Ultima Online</link></style>, maintained aspects of this by letting players buy (and thereby build) houses. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Superstruct">Superstruct</link></style> shows how <style="CurrentLink">Construction</style> can be used to stimulate players to create and describe future versions of themselves and how big scale modern day problem can be solved.

Players of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Warhammer%20Fantasy%20Battle">Warhammer Fantasy Battle</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Warhammer%2040K">Warhammer 40K</link></style> need to construct the armies which they intended to play with using ones they have purchased. The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Collectible%20Card%20Games">Collectible Card Games</link></style> <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Magic:%20The%20Gathering">Magic: The Gathering</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pok%C3%A9mon%20Trading%20Card%20Game">Pokémon Trading Card Game</link></style> work in a similar fashion. For those participating in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Live%20Action%20Roleplaying%20Games">Live Action Roleplaying Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/1942%20%E2%80%93%20Noen%20%C3%A5%20stole%20p%C3%A5">1942 – Noen å stole på</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragonbane">Dragonbane</link></style> need to create not only some items with narrative importance, such as full-scale dragons, but also everyday utensils and clothing.

The design of <style="CurrentLink">Construction</style> consists of choosing what game elements (or other material) is the basis for the activity, what the end result of the activity is, and what is required to be able to perform the activity. Using <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> ensure that these choices can be done on a case-by-case basis and do not have to be done before they become relevant, but otherwise the choices need to be done earlier. <style="Link"><link="crafting">Crafting</link></style> is the more specific activity resulting in <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style>. While the <style="CurrentLink">Construction</style> pattern is more literally design through letting players change <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, it can also be supported in a more abstract fashion through letting them construct structures or functionalities in <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-constructs">Abstract Player Constructs</link></style>, e.g. <style="Link"><link="gameplay-engines">Gameplay Engines</link></style>.

There are many possible type of game elements usable as building materials but examples include <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> (in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Warhammer%20Fantasy%20Battle">Warhammer Fantasy Battle</link></style>) and <style="Link"><link="tiles">Tiles</link></style> (in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Carcassonne">Carcassonne</link></style>). Since <style="CurrentLink">Construction</style> cannot typically be done without any restrictions, the material chosen becomes a <style="Link"><link="resources">Resource</link></style> if it was not already. <style="CurrentLink">Construction</style> do not need any base material but if this is the case there is typically some other <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> linked to the action, or the action has limitations (e.g. through <style="Link"><link="action-caps">Action Caps</link></style>). The game elements used for <style="CurrentLink">Construction</style> can come from a number of different source. One is from outside the game as <style="Link"><link="game-element-insertion">Game Element Insertion</link></style>, while another is that they are created by the game system and a third is that they are simply rearranged within the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> through <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style>.

While perhaps <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style> are not so often used as the material for <style="CurrentLink">Construction</style>, they are in games with <style="Link"><link="card-building">Card</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="deck-building">Deck Building</link></style> or those with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pre-Customized%20Decks">Pre-Customized Decks</link></style>. In these they serve the purpose of being the material to create or modifying <style="Link"><link="decks">Decks</link></style>.

Besides being building material, <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> can also be the end result of <style="CurrentLink">Construction</style>, and by using these patterns in this way one modifies their presence. Similarly, allowing <style="Link"><link="bases">Bases</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="installations">Installations</link></style> to be constructed is a way of letting this pattern modify how those patterns function. Another possible end result is the <style="CurrentLink">Construction</style> of permanent <style="Link"><link="combos">Combos</link></style>, which for example success in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Puerto%20Rico">Puerto Rico</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Race%20for%20the%20Galaxy">Race for the Galaxy</link></style> depend upon. These <style="Link"><link="combos">Combos</link></style> can intentionally be put into the game design as a way to modulate <style="CurrentLink">Construction</style> but can also easily emerge as an effect. How <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="ai-players">AI Players</link></style> should behave is another possible outcome of <style="CurrentLink">Construction</style>, found for example in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/P-Robots">P-Robots</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Crobots">Crobots</link></style>. This is most often done through some form of <style="Link"><link="action-programming">Action Programming</link></style>, and is one of the ways players can have influence in <style="Link"><link="zero-player-games">Zero-Player Games</link></style>. The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Player%20Constructed%20Worlds">Player Constructed Worlds</link></style> of early <style="Link"><link="massively-multiplayer-online-games">Massively Multiplayer Online Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Kingdoms">Kingdoms</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/DragonMud">DragonMud</link></style> take <style="CurrentLink">Construction</style> further since the actual <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> are the result of player <style="CurrentLink">Construction</style>, and providing this type of player activity gives a possibility for <style="Link"><link="varied-gameplay">Varied Gameplay</link></style> to players given this power. This is taken one step further in games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Conway's%20Game%20of%20Life">Conway's Game of Life</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Minecraft">Minecraft</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Slaves%20to%20Armok%20II:%20Dwarf%20Fortress">Slaves to Armok II: Dwarf Fortress</link></style>, where players construct computers to be able to code within the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>. Where players have to create the game elements used for gameplay, i.e. games with <style="Link"><link="heterogeneous-game-element-ownership">Heterogeneous Game Element Ownership</link></style>, this forces players to engage in <style="CurrentLink">Construction</style> (or <style="Link"><link="trading">Trading</link></style> as <style="Link"><link="extra-game-actions">Extra-Game Actions</link></style>).

When building materials are <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> having these naturally become a requirement for <style="CurrentLink">Construction</style>, and can motivate have support for <style="Link"><link="trading">Trading</link></style> activities and provide the basis for <style="Link"><link="game-world-exploration">Game World Exploration</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style> goals. Another common requirement (e.g. in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Age%20of%20Empires%20series">Age of Empires series</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Civilization%20(video%20game)%20series">Civilization series</link></style>) is to require a certain <style="Link"><link="development-time">Development Time</link></style> for the <style="CurrentLink">Construction</style> to be finished. The amount of <style="CurrentLink">Construction</style> in a game can easily be limited by making it a <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style> (as for example in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Team%20Fortress%20series">Team Fortress series</link></style>). In <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Massively%20Single-Player%20Games">Massively Single-Player Games</link></style> with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Neighbors">Neighbors</link></style>, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/CityVille">CityVille</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Empires%20&%20Allies">Empires & Allies</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="altruistic-actions">Altruistic Actions</link></style> by the other players may also be needed (diegetically this is often explained as filling occupational positions).

The will of players to engage in <style="CurrentLink">Construction</style> can be reduced if they constructions can be destroyed through <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style> by <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style>. For <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> this includes other players, and this may make <style="CurrentLink">Construction</style> more suitable to modulate <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style>, which can still be noticeable by others, <style="Link"><link="spectators">Spectators</link></style>, through <style="Link"><link="extra-game-broadcasting">Extra-Game Broadcasting</link></style> (the various youtube videos from <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Minecraft">Minecraft</link></style> are examples of this, as is the stories created using the various installments in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Sims%20series">Sims series</link></style>). Although the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style> of building something that may be destroyed can be desired by the designers, if <style="CurrentLink">Construction</style> is to be promoted this can be done by creating <style="Link"><link="private-game-spaces">Private Game Spaces</link></style> or making them into <style="Link"><link="irreversible-events">Irreversible Events</link></style>. When promote in this way, <style="CurrentLink">Construction</style> makes sense as a way of providing <style="Link"><link="casual-gameplay">Casual Gameplay</link></style>.

An additional type of outcome of <style="CurrentLink">Construction</style> is the <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style> of a game, something common in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Roleplaying%20Games">Roleplaying Games</link></style>. This can require <style="Link"><link="storytelling">Storytelling</link></style> from both players and <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> and can support <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Never%20Ending%20Stories">Never Ending Stories</link></style> since the stories can be added to as gameplay progresses.

<style="CurrentLink">Construction</style> allows the creation and modification of <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> and can easily gives rise to <style="Link"><link="safe-havens">Safe Havens</link></style> as well as <style="Link"><link="combos">Combos</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Emergent%20Gameplay">Emergent Gameplay</link></style> if sufficiently many combinations are possible. Knowing about these effects from <style="Link"><link="experimenting">Experimenting</link></style> (or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Trans-Game%20Information">Trans-Game Information</link></style>) is a form of <style="Link"><link="strategic-knowledge">Strategic Knowledge</link></style> and often part of what is required to have <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style> in games focusing on <style="CurrentLink">Construction</style>. When <style="CurrentLink">Construction</style> depends on the help of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Neighbors">Neighbors</link></style> through <style="Link"><link="altruistic-actions">Altruistic Actions</link></style>, this can put players in a position of <style="Link"><link="helplessness">Helplessness</link></style> if such actions do not occur. <style="Link"><link="preventing-goals">Preventing Goals</link></style> can occur when several <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> can perform <style="CurrentLink">Construction</style> but wish to do different types of constructions in the same space. This is one way of creating <style="Link"><link="preventing-goals">Preventing Goals</link></style> which are not (necessarily) <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style>-oriented.

The introduction of game elements through <style="CurrentLink">Construction</style> is functionally similar to the effect of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Producers">Producers</link></style> but does not need to use <style="Link"><link="spawning">Spawning</link></style>. As such, <style="CurrentLink">Construction</style> often provides <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> to diegetic game elements and can more easily be given representations that allow the introduction of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Game%20Elements">Game Elements</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> without breaking <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style>. Heavy focus on <style="CurrentLink">Construction</style> in some parts of a game instance can create <style="Link"><link="expansion">Expansion</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="exploitation">Exploitation</link></style> phases depending on if new game elements are produced or existing ones improved.

<style="CurrentLink">Construction</style> actions typically represent <style="Link"><link="investments">Investments</link></style> and are perceived as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Constructive%20Gameplay">Constructive Gameplay</link></style>. If they can be destroyed through <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style>, these <style="Link"><link="investments">Investments</link></style> provide an even higher level of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style> than only having invested wrongly. With enough possible permutations in what and how to construct things, the pattern gives <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Creative%20Control">Creative Control</link></style> which in turn can lead to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Surprises">Surprises</link></style>, both for themselves and others. When permutations can be used to explain what is possible to construct, it however also means that it is limited in some way and therefore an example of <style="Link"><link="framed-freedom">Framed Freedom</link></style>. With <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Creative%20Control">Creative Control</link></style> comes the additional possibility of <style="Link"><link="player-defined-goals">Player-Defined Goals</link></style> (and adopting these can be said to be a requirement for games such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/SimCity%20series">SimCity series</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/FarmVille">FarmVille</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Minecraft">Minecraft</link></style> to be games), and since players in most cases can themselves choose how hard they need to struggle for these goals games with these structures are also suitable for <style="Link"><link="pottering">Pottering</link></style>. All of these effects make it quite likely that <style="Link"><link="stimulated-planning">Stimulated Planning</link></style> rises from <style="CurrentLink">Construction</style>. <style="Link"><link="gameplay-engines">Gameplay Engines</link></style> can be created through <style="CurrentLink">Construction</style> in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> even if <style="Link"><link="gameplay-engines">Gameplay Engines</link></style> probably more often and easier are designed as features of <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-constructs">Abstract Player Constructs</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Construction</style> can easily represent <style="Link"><link="persistent-game-world-changes">Persistent Game World Changes</link></style> in games. When it exists in <style="Link"><link="persistent-game-worlds">Persistent Game Worlds</link></style>, or where players can activate <style="Link"><link="extra-game-broadcasting">Extra-Game Broadcasting</link></style>, the pattern can have a higher <style="Link"><link="value-effort">Value of Effort</link></style> since other players (and <style="Link"><link="spectators">Spectators</link></style>) can observe the outcomes of the activities, especially when do not need to worry about them being destroy due to being <style="Link"><link="irreversible-events">Irreversible Events</link></style>. When taken to a more pervasive level, <style="CurrentLink">Construction</style> enables <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Player%20Constructed%20Worlds">Player Constructed Worlds</link></style>. This does necessarily make the elements into <style="Link"><link="player-created-game-elements">Player Created Game Elements</link></style>, for this to occur some level of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Creative%20Control">Creative Control</link></style> or actual craftsmanship is required. The <style="CurrentLink">Construction</style> of <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> by players however leads to the presence of <style="Link"><link="player-created-characters">Player-Created Characters</link></style>, regardless if they are actually to be used as <style="Link"><link="player-characters">Player Characters</link></style> (most but not all <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Roleplaying%20Games">RPGs</link></style>), <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style> (e.g. the 'grogs' and 'companions' in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ars%20Magica">Ars Magica</link></style>), or <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style> (e.g. 'dependents' in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style>). When players have to construct the actual materials used to play the game, <style="CurrentLink">Construction</style> supports <style="Link"><link="heterogeneous-game-element-ownership">Heterogeneous Game Element Ownership</link></style>.

When <style="Link"><link="tiles">Tiles</link></style> are used for the <style="CurrentLink">Construction</style> of <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Carcassonne">Carcassonne</link></style>) or abstract structure (like the power structures in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Illuminati">Illuminati</link></style>, this gives rise to <style="Link"><link="tile-laying">Tile-Laying</link></style>. This can - despite the name of the resulting pattern - be done with <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Tokens">Tokens</link></style> as well.

<style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="casual-gameplay">Casual Gameplay</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="combos">Combos</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Constructive%20Gameplay">Constructive Gameplay</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Creative%20Control">Creative Control</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Emergent%20Gameplay">Emergent Gameplay</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="expansion">Expansion</link></style>,
